comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Here is a wonderful contemporary newspaper description of the first passenger train on this line in 1894. Not this particular train - they used Mr Danaher's, though Messrs Kerle get a mention. The passengers sat on slabs on the flatbed trucks, with a band and a choir, showers of sparks from the engine, attempted derailment etc - read all about it - Northern Star (Lismore) 17/01/1894 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/72419807 .

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Such astonishing detail in those old newspaper stories! I wonder how the historians of the future will manage to recreate the past with today's drivel?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] It is a ripper, isn't it?  Really brings the ho-hum photo to life.  I even went along for the ride using Google Earth, trying to spot the landmarks described.

I think that the distance of time lends enchantment both to the photo and article.  If it happened last week in the local rag, I would be yawning!

comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] The photo isn't that ho hum is it?? ;)
Great article thanks for the link!
-AG

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] Apologies! "Ho-hum" might be too strong a description for this wonderful old photo. Old trains do not normally grab my interest, because I do not know enough about them - mea culpa.
